docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, Greece had a typical European health system offering universal care, but the unemployed are now often left on their own if they get sick.

headline.seo: Greek Unemployed Cut Off From Medical Treatment
headline.main: Amid Cutbacks, Greek Doctors Offer Message to Poor: You Are Not Alone
headline.print_headline: Amid Cutbacks, Greek Doctors Offer Message to Poor: You Are Not Alone

docs.abstract: Greek doctors have formed underground movement to care for unemployed people who are unable to afford cost of healthcare due to austerity measures that have severely limited access to nation's once-universal healthcare system.
docs.snippet: Until recently, Greece had a typical European health system offering universal care, but the unemployed are now often left on their own if they get sick.

docs.lead_paragraph: In some states, women with dense tissue must now be told that it could increase their risk of cancer, which medical groups said would lead to needless testing.

headline.seo: Laws Tell Mammogram Clinics to Address Breast Density
headline.main: New Laws Add a Divisive Component to Breast Screening
headline.print_headline: Laws Add Dimension, and Questions, to Breast Cancer Screening

docs.abstract: States are passing laws requiring clinics that perform mammograms to tell patients whether they have something known as dense breast tissue, and that it can hide tumors during a screening, increasing risk of breast cancer; laws are being cheered by patient advocates but medical groups, arguing the significance of tissue density, say that it will lead to needless additional tests; laws requiring disclosure have been passed in Connecticut, Texas, Virginia, California and New York.
docs.snippet: In some states, women with dense tissue must now be told that it could increase their risk of cancer, which medical groups said would lead to needless testing.

docs.abstract: The safety-net programs in the federal stimulus that helped fight the recession came at a cost of weakening incentives to work or hire.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Paul Butler created a stir when he suggested ending football at Dover High School in New Hampshire, citing evidence of the peril the sport poses to the brains of players.

headline.seo: A Town’s Passion, a Retired Doctor’s Concern
headline.main: A Town’s Passion for Football, a Retired Doctor’s Concern
headline.print_headline: A Town’s Passion, a Retired Doctor’s Concern

docs.abstract: Retired doctor and Dover, NH, school board member Paul Butler stirs controversy by calling for an end to town's high school football program; cites evidence about dangers of repeated head trauma and concussions and warns of possible lawsuits by former players.
docs.snippet: Dr. Paul Butler created a stir when he suggested ending football at Dover High School in New Hampshire, citing evidence of the peril the sport poses to the brains of players.

docs.lead_paragraph: Depending on who is doing the talking these days, New York State is either a national model of how to curb Medicaid spending, or the nation’s prime example of Medicaid abuse.

headline.seo: New York’s Medicaid Program Is at the Mercy of Washington
headline.main: Cuomo’s Medicaid Changes Are at Washington’s Mercy
headline.print_headline: Cuomo’s Medicaid Changes Are at Washington’s Mercy

docs.abstract: Federal officials are holding New York responsible for $15 billion in Medicaid overpayments to the state’s centers for the developmentally disabled over two decades; issue is clearly becoming a headache for the state as presidential campaign focus turns to Medicare.
docs.snippet: Depending on who is doing the talking these days, New York State is either a national model of how to curb Medicaid spending, or the nation’s prime example of Medicaid abuse.

headline.main: The Health Mandate Romney Still Supports

docs.abstract: The Republicans seem perfectly content to mandate emergency care by hospitals while opposing the individual health-care mandate of the Affordable Care Act.
